source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: the variable $F _ { \mathrm { s o l } }$ is introduced [6,21]. The additive nature of dislocation substructure strengthening and solute strengthening suggests that the two variables should enter as $F _ { \mathrm { s o l } } + F _ { \mathrm { d e f } }$ [22]. The fact that dislocation-solute interactions such as solute drag depend on both dislocation velocities and solute diffusion rates [23] suggests that ${ \pmb F } _ { \mathrm { s o l } }$ should depend on strain rate and temperature; for simplicity, ${ \pmb F } _ { \mathbf { s o l } }$ is made a function of $\dot { \epsilon } / \theta ^ { \prime }$ .With this form, the equations show (1) a yield strength plateau [24], (2) reduced or possibly negative strain-rate sensitivity in the dynamic strain aging regime, and (3) changes in steady-state creep behavior associated with solute strengthening.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: irradiation hardening (it is incorporated with the $\pmb { F } _ { \mathrm { d e f } }$ variable)

evidence_span: irradiation-enhanced creep (a separate irradiation-induced creep rate $\dot { \epsilon } _ { \mathrm { i r t } }$ is added to the thermal creep rate $\dot { \epsilon } _ { \mathfrak { t h } }$ )

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: Figure 4 gives an estimate of $d \epsilon _ { \tt c } / d \epsilon _ { \tt a }$ as a function of temperature and material condition. Note that the material tends toward isotropy $( d \epsilon _ { \mathrm { { c } } } / d \epsilon _ { \mathrm { { a } } }$ $\ l \to \ 1 )$ at high temperatures. Note also that strain aging may lead to a reversal in anisotropy $( d \epsilon _ { \tt c } / d \epsilon _ { \tt a } > 1 )$ in fully recrystallized material [3]. Finally, note that irradiation suppresses the strain-aging response, and irradiated material is expected to exhibit behavior similar to that of unirradiated, cold-worked material.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: Figure 4 gives an estimate of $d \epsilon _ { \tt c } / d \epsilon _ { \tt a }$ as a function of temperature and material condition. Note that the material tends toward isotropy $( d \epsilon _ { \mathrm { { c } } } / d \epsilon _ { \mathrm { { a } } }$ $\ l \to \ 1 )$ at high temperatures. Note also that strain aging may lead to a reversal in anisotropy $( d \epsilon _ { \tt c } / d \epsilon _ { \tt a } > 1 )$ in fully recrystallized material [3]. Finally, note that irradiation suppresses the strain-aging response, and irradiated material is expected to exhibit behavior similar to that of unirradiated, cold-worked material.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: The changes in crystallographic texture of Zircaloy-2 specimens during plastic deformation have recently been investigated by Ballinger, Lucas, and Pelloux [3]. Their results offer the prospect of a more physically based anisotropy model with reduced data requirements.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_026_chunk6
evidence_span: Preliminary analysis of these data shows texture rotation to be (1) dependent on initial texture and direction of the stress tensor, (2) related to the plastic strain in an approximately linear way, and (3) only slightly dependent on temperature and strain rate.
